Pet peeve. The increasingly scarcity of intersections where you can turn right on read. When the right-on-red law passed, decades ago, you could practically turn right on red at any given intersection, and that freedom has slowly been curtailed, intersection by intersection. Having just been to the Met‚Äôs blockbuster show ‚ÄúDivine Egypt‚Äù twice in the last month (I live across the park, lucky me :)) I might as well try to share some of that esoteric knowledge here. 

Cow horns were most closely associated with the goddess Hathor,m; over time (and we are talking about millennia so there‚Äôs lots of time!) depictions of ISIS also took on cow horns, in line with the general syncretic practice of Egyptian religious iconography.

Of course, the clue is not wrong per se; indeed the reference to cow horns can be read as the hint that we are looking for an ancient Egyptian deity. And the answer to ‚ÄúEgyptian goddess, four letters‚Äù is always going to be ISIS. I didn‚Äôt spend a lot of time trying to use a rebus to fit ‚ÄúHathor‚Äù in there. 

Now, this being the NYXW comments there is probably a world-class Egyptologist among us who will either correct me or add much more erudition ‚Ä¶

A rebus you have to do in your own head rather than filling in.¬† How will the online puzzle apps know if you actually "got" it?¬† They probably won't, but that's not my concern since I solve on paper.

I had a nice Aha Moment when I saw the revealer and realized that COMEREDASS was going to = COMES TO PASS and that WORKINGREENIT would = WORKING ON IT.¬† After which I filled in the last RED and GREEN and this very easy puzzle¬†became even easier.¬†
¬†
But as long as it puzzled me for a little while, I was happy with it.¬† The embedding of the STOPs was more difficult than the embedding of the GOs -- and therefore I was more impressed with them.

A couple of nits.¬† Would anyone say "I STETTED that"?¬† Seems like a MUWOC¬†("Made-up word of convenience".¬† Can I trademark that?)¬† And a feeling of AWE (the night sky with a full moon; the Grand Canyon) is quite different from being "flabbergasted" ("you're telling me that he walked naked through Yankee Stadium???").¬† One has a spiritual component and one doesn't.

This brings to mind the recent "grade inflation" puzzle, which many solvers, including myself, viewed a rebus, while others chided "No, no, no! It's a letter-substitution one!" 

I should point out that in Latin, the word "rebus" means (abl./dat.) "for the things,"--i.e. "in place of . . ."--in which case even a letter-substitution would qualify as a rebus. Tricksy is as tricksy does.

(The Latin word "res" is hard to translate, as it has so many usages--it can mean "object," "situation," "(legal) case," "affair (of State--it's the "re-" in "republic")".  But then, originally so did the Germanic "thing"--isn't the Icelandic parliament called the Althing?)

(Copied from a reply I left in a thread below, except I corrected the spelling of "Althing.")

The whole question of whether this is a rebus or not is a great demonstration of how  actual things escape the boundaries of our definitions.

If we can't agree of what a rebus is, or we can't fit this particular example into the definition of rebus, what hope do we have for words like patriotism, compassion, empathy, dedication or any of the other words that are foundational to our culture?

Heidi,
The first kind of rebus  Deb mentions often uses images, not just symbols, to represent letters or words (i.e., a picture of a bee for the letter B). In this puzzle, a GREEN (traffic light) represents "go" twice, and a RED (traffic light) represents "stop" twice. Since the "images" are in your mind, you could argue that they aren't "really" rebuses, but then, squishing two or more letters into one square is even less a rebus except as Crosslandia claims it to be.

@Heidi et @lii:
This brings to mind the recent "grade inflation" puzzle, which many solvers, including myself, viewed a rebus, while others chided "No, no, no! It's a letter-substitution one!" 

I should point out that in Latin, the word "rebus" means (abl./dat.) "for the things,"--i.e. "in place of . . ."--in which case even a letter-substitution would qualify as a rebus. Tricksy is as tricksy does.

(The Latin word "res" is hard to translate, as it has so many usages--it can mean "object," "situation," "(legal) case," "affair (of State--it's the "re-" in "republic").  But then, originally so did the Germanic "thing'--isn't the Icelandic parliament called the Allthing?

Actually, there has never been any debate about what constitutes a rebus. In crosswords, it‚Äôs when you have to cram more than one letter, or use numerals or symbols in certain squares. (You could also draw illustrations of those letter strings if they constitute real words, such as drawing stars in the rebus boxes if the string of letters is STAR.)

Outside of crosswords, a rebus is a puzzle consisting of mostly pictures that must be parsed to make up a familiar word or phrase. The classic TV game show Concentration features those. 

These two different phenomena were the only two types of rebus that existed. Until today, when Sam called today‚Äôs shenanigans a rebus, and a few people (although a minority) argued that maybe it is. 

It isn‚Äôt. Widening the definition of what is considered a rebus serves no positive purpose; to the contrary, it sows confusion.
